And before you bring it up, nine months of pregnancy is not a reasonable step.

From the Wall Street Journal:
 
 What the Guru And the Philosopher Can't Tell You
 By COLIN MCGINN
 November 3, 2005; Page D8
 When people ask, "What's the meaning of life?" they often seek some item of esoteric knowledge that will make sense of their existence -- to be supplied by a guru, a religious leader or a Deep Philosopher. The question is taken to be asking why we are here -- what the ultimate purpose of human life is. This purpose might originate in God or evolution or even in aliens from outer space: X put us here to achieve purpose P. The question is then what to put for X and P.
 
 But that can't be right, as Julian Baggini argues in his useful and provocative "What's It All About?" At most we will claim to know what X's purpose was in putting us here, not what our goals and values ought to be. A deity might have created us to worship him, but this might not provide much meaning for us (we might prefer to be worshipped ourselves). Genes might have put us here to serve as vehicles of their reproduction, but why should we care about their purposes?
 
 Thus the causal origin of the human race is the wrong place to look for what gives meaning to life. And this is a good thing, because it is at best a moot point whether the universe has any purpose at all: It might simply be. If this is at least a possibility, we want to be able to find a meaning in life that issues from life itself, not from what purposely gave rise to it.
 
 We should first replace the question with its plural version: "What are the meanings of life?" That is, what values are worth pursuing? The altruist will say that the prime meaning in life derives from helping others. Mr. Baggini makes the excellent point that there is something inconsistent in this attitude, if it insists on excessive self-sacrifice. Helping others is good only because of the improvement that is made in other people's lives -- but then the key value is living what he calls a "full and flourishing life." If it is good to promote such lives in others, then it is good to enjoy such a life oneself. So the value of altruism lies not in the helping but in the end achieved. If so, our focus must be on what makes a life full and flourishing.
 
 Happiness is the natural answer. But there are problems: What kind of happiness? That of the aesthete, the moralist or the sensualist? And what is happiness, anyway -- a momentary feeling, a lasting disposition, a mere absence of misery? How is it to be achieved? Perhaps not by pursuing it directly but by pursuing other purposes, of which happiness is an offshoot or byproduct. But then those purposes need to be identified and will constitute the underlying values.
 
 And there is this problem: What if someone offered you the chance to live inside a "happiness machine" that simulated the joyful life, as you understand it, but that involved no actual relationships or achievements or even truth (rather like the "Matrix" movies)? You would experience a lot of happiness but would be living a fake existence: Wouldn't all that pleasant emotion be hollow and meaningless?
 
 This possibility suggests that some notion of authenticity and genuine achievement is necessary for a meaningful life, not merely agreeable affect. As Mr. Baggini notes, we needn't restrict such achievement to the artist or scientist or entrepreneur; everyone strives for success in one form or another, even if it is "just" being part of a loving family. People need to achieve worthwhile goals if they are to feel satisfied with their lives, but the goals may vary. Above all, people need to become the kind of person they individually aspire to be.
 
 The mistake is to make one value dominant over all others, as if a single goal will confer meaning on life for all. Instead we need a list: happiness, altruism, achievement, learning, self-expression, personal relations. Such a list supplies what Mr. Baggini calls a "deflationary" answer to the question of life's meaning. It is not some hidden and inaccessible secret, available only to the initiated or requiring a leap of faith. Rather, it consists of things that everyone already knows, even if in an unarticulated form. It is not a matter of where we came from or where we might be going. Rather, it is a matter of the very pith and marrow of life as it is lived. We each have a responsibility to select the values we shall live by and to pursue them with vigor; we cannot appeal to some outside authority to relieve us of this obligation. We must find a meaning in life, not suppose that the meaning is conferred by something outside it.
 
 Of course, this is the standard secular approach to the question. Having accepted that human existence is itself purposeless, a mere accident of cosmic evolution, we feel obliged to find meaning within that given life -- in the values that reason identifies. Our lives will then have value to us, even if not to any external agency.
 
 Mr. Baggini is articulating such a secular view, and I am with him in dismissing other approaches -- not so much because they are false factually as because they do not really answer the question they purport to: namely, how we should live in order to have meaningful lives. God is not so much dead as irrelevant by this reckoning, at least when it comes to deciding what gives life meaning, since we have to ask which values from the religious tradition really confer value on life, by our own standards.
 
 The question that remains, not taken up by Mr. Baggini, is whether this kind of deflationary secular answer is enough. Most people will agree with the list he offers and live according to it, but they may still have a nagging feeling that more is required for life to be anything other than a brief and inglorious cosmic bleep. That may be irrational, a kind of pointless overreaching, but it may yet be what the majority of mankind is condemned to feel.
 
 Mr. McGinn's latest book is "Mindsight: Image, Dream, Meaning" (Harvard University Press).
